channel.title: Getting Stamped
channel.description: Figuring out life one stamp at a time...

item.title: Best day trips in Mexico
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.description: The white sand beaches are reason enough to make the trip to the Yucatan, but wait there’s more! We have complied a list of our favorite activities and excursions. Mayan Ruins There are several Mayan sites within an hour or Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The white sand beaches are reason enough to make the trip to the Yucatan, but wait there’s more! We have complied a list of our favorite activities and excursions.

Mayan Ruins

There are several Mayan sites within an hour or so from the coast, all offering a little something different, but all a great day trip.

Tulum Ruins -  is a unique site, set on the cliffs over looking the water just outside the main city center. Mayan ruins set amongst palm trees with the electric blue water behind them, it is truly remarkable.

  Coba Ruins – located about 2.5 hours from the resorts in Cancun lies the Mayan site of Coba. This site is unique for its jungle setting, the site is clear to see all of the structure but you still feel like your are in the jungle. Coba is about 45 minutes away from the resorts of Tulum, and about 2-2.5 hours from Cancun.

The Watch Tower at Coba

 Chichen Itza – One of the largest, and most famous Mayan sites in Mexico. The site hosts one of the icon Mayan style pyramids.

Cenotes

 A cenote is a collapsed, under ground, limestone cave, and the Yucatan is full of them. The caves played a significant roll in Mayan life, and make for a great day trip. Snorkeling and diving is available at most sites, most times there is an entrance fee, and another for gear rental or you can purchase your trip through most resorts.

Akumal

Just north of Tulum, Akumal is a small beach with a few resorts but the main draw here is the Turtles. This beach during many parts of the year is FULL of sea turtles! Snorkel gear is available to rent, and just off shore you can swim with more turtles than I have ever seen in one place. There are plenty of shops and restaurants, along with a pretty beach to make a full day of it.

Valladolid

This colonial city is a bit off the beaten track, but is worth a visit for some relaxation in the park. Valladolid is reasonably close to Chichen Itza and could be a combined trip. The colonial buildings and cathedrals can fill up a few hours and your camera’s memory card.

 When visiting the yucatan make sure to find your way off the beach (well at least for a day!) to checkout some of the areas other attractions.

item.title: Taking In The Beauty Of Aberdeen And The Surrounding Area
item.dc:creator: Guest Poster
item.description: Aberdeen is an area of breath taking beauty, both natural and architectural. If you’re planning on visiting there are many exceptional places to see, especially if you can access the surrounding areas.   In the city itself it’s all about Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Aberdeen is an area of breath taking beauty, both natural and architectural. If you’re planning on visiting there are many exceptional places to see, especially if you can access the surrounding areas.

 

In the city itself it’s all about the architecture. Aberdeen Art Gallery is the city’s most popular tourist attraction and is a beautiful example of late 19th century design. It contains works from as far back as the 15th century in the form of paintings, graphics and sculptures. Another building as stunning on the inside as the outside is the award winning Maritime Museum. As you’d expect, this museum exhibits the city’s rich maritime heritage including shipbuilding, fishing, fast sailing ships and port history. The museum also has the best viewpoint to see over Aberdeen’s busy harbour. Staying on the nautical tip, Footdee (pronounced Fittie) is a quaint old fishing village. You can enjoy a relaxing afternoon wandering down its narrow streets and enjoying the tiny houses by the sea.

Duthie Park is 44 acres of delightful parkland donated by Miss Duthie to the city in the late 1800s. It contains many artefacts including fountains, ponds, statues and a bandstand. It also surrounds The Winter Gardens . Rebuilt in 1970, this glass structure houses exotic plants and the largest cactus collection in Britain. In the summer you can go boating on the ponds and play cricket on the lawns. Another summer-only attraction is the Pitmedden Garden & Museum of Farming Life. The ornate gardens are immaculately kept and the museum is fascinating, but it’s the strong ties with the community that make it worth a visit. Every summer plays, musicals and concerts are hosted in the grounds turning the gardens into a beautiful outdoor theatre.

Venturing further out of Aberdeen, Craigievar castle is an essential visit. Its fairy-tale appearance needs to be seen to be believed. Linn O Dee is an area of outstanding beauty depicting the rugged Scottish countryside at its best. It’s a long but worthwhile drive to see the roaring waterfall tumbling over jagged rocks. If golf is your hobby then the award winning Royal Aberdeen Golf Club will allow you to take in the rolling greens of Scotland’s landscape whilst also perfecting your swing.

There are plenty of hotels to stay at in Aberdeen and the surrounding area. The best thing to do is choose a hotel with a car park in the city so you can benefit from the central attractions and restaurants and then drive out and immerse yourself in Scotland’s natural beauty on the road.

~ The above is a guest post from Mercure.com ~ For more info on our guest posts see our Guest Post Details ~

item.title: Meet a Traveler- Interview with Wanderlusters
item.dc:creator: Hannah
item.description: Interview with Charli & Ben from Wanderlusters The who are you ?’s 1. Who are you and where do you hail from? We are Charli & Ben a nomadic couple originally from the UK. 2. How did you meet your Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Interview with Charli & Ben from Wanderlusters

The who are you ?’s

1. Who are you and where do you hail from?
We are Charli & Ben a nomadic couple originally from the UK.

2. How did you meet your partner in crime? How long have you known each other?
I (Charli) went to school with Ben’s younger sister and fell for my friend’s charming older brother. 8 years later we’re still together.

3. What jobs did you kick to the curb in order to travel?
I worked as a gallery assistant for an independent art gallery in London, facilitating exhibitions at the director’s request.
Ben worked as an IT project manager for a large multinational, he spent his days managing huge projects all over the UK and his evenings sitting in rush hour traffic.

4. Explain your website name, where did it come from/how did you come up with it?
The definition of ‘Wanderlust’ is ‘a very strong or irresistible impulse to travel’ after a long brain storming session we chose the name ‘Wanderlusters’ as it conveys our desire for adventure perfectly.

The fun ?’s

1. What’s the most under-estimated country & why?
We spent eleven months road tripping around Australia during 2012 and seriously under estimated the diverse wealth of environments to explore. The country is so vast and although we were on the road almost non-stop and covered 25,000km, we only scratched the surface.

2. What’s your biggest travel mishap?
We found ourselves stranded in the remote mining town of Gove in the Northern Territory last year. I also left Ben’s cagoule on a bus in Costa Rica…during rainy season.

3. What luxuries did you forgo in order to save for your travels?
We (Ben) have always been really careful with money and consider every penny we spend. During the six months prior to our departure we gave up our flat in West London and moved home, avoided eating out and paying for anything unnecessary. I’d like to say I gave up my skin care routine also, but that would be fibbing!

4. What country has the best $1usd menu? What can one expect to get for $1usd?
Nicaragua provided a veritable feast of delights for pennies. Bus travel is the best way to sample traditional food. Pulling into a bus station passengers get off and women loaded with delicious handmade snacks get on. You can feast like a king for $1.

Quick & Dirty (1-2 word answers)

1.    Favorite beach
Charli: Valla Beach NSW Australia
Ben: Ojochal, Southern Costa Rica

2.    1 must have travel items
Charli: A good book
Ben: Laptop/Camera it’s too close to call

3.    Zip-off pants or no zip-off pants
Both: What on earth are zip-off pants?!

4.    Favorite beer
Charli: I hate to break it to Adam but I’m more of a G&T girl.
Ben: Leffe, a great Belgian brew

5.    Favorite ice-cream flavour
Charli: Coconut
Ben: Peanut Butter Chunk

6.    How many stamps in your passport?
Charli: 16
Ben: 21

Facebook page link: http://www.facebook.com/Wanderlusters
Twitter page link: https://twitter.com/wanderlustersuk
Webpage link: http://wanderlusters.co.uk/

item.title: So much to look forward to…
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.description: I have been asked by almost all of my friends “what part of your trip are you looking forward to most?” That’s a tough question cause there I sooooo much to look forward to with a 700+ day long trip. Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
I have been asked by almost all of my friends “what part of your trip are you looking forward to most?” That’s a tough question cause there I sooooo much to look forward to with a 700+ day long trip. But I think if there is one place that sticks out in my mind its Turkey.

It’s now or never for Turkey

In the past year I have had several friends travel to Turkey, and just a few years ago they probably couldn’t have told you were Turkey even was. Tourism is really booming right now and already I read other blogs about how expensive it is getting, and that it’s changing fast. One main theme of our trip is to see the developing places in the world as they are now, before they see more development and change even further.

Continental cross roads

There is something very intriguing about  being split between to contents and all of the cultures that passed through. We plan to hit Turkey sometime in the summer or fall of 2014. We aren’t 100% sure from where we will enter the country, but flights to turkey seem to be reasonable from many cities.

Fairy Chasing

By now the it’s seems everyone has heard of the fairy chimneys of Cappadocia, but I still want to see them for myself. From everything I have seen I think  the perfect way to visit them is by a sunrise, hot air balloon ride over the site. I am not the biggest fan of heights, but his for sure makes my top 10 things I am most excited about!

Ice Cream!

Hannah is also excited for her Turkish ice cream experience (if she has the patience to wait for her cone!) Ice cream vendors around the markets are as much of a show as they are a snack. You have got to have quick hands too or you might end up hungry! The vendors will play slight hand tricks as they pass you the cone.

Video from: jdolecek on YouTube

item.title: Discover Canada
item.dc:creator: Guest Poster
item.description: Being the second largest country in the world, Canada has such geographic diversity that will astonish even the most experience travelers: exciting vibrant cities, beautiful mountains and rivers, waterfalls, national parks and historic sites. Every traveler has to discover Canada Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Being the second largest country in the world, Canada has such geographic diversity that will astonish even the most experience travelers: exciting vibrant cities, beautiful mountains and rivers, waterfalls, national parks and historic sites.

Every traveler has to discover Canada for themselves and feel its natural beauty. Just book a flight to Toronto that best suits you, hop on the plane, and enjoy one of the most spectacular destinations in the world.

When someone says “Visit to Canada” the first thing that comes to mind is Niagara Falls. More than 12 million visitors go to Ontario every year with only one intention: to enjoy this miracle. The three Niagara Falls are actually one of the natural wanders of the world. Maybe the best way to fully enjoy the experience is taking one of the Maid of the Mist boats which will give you an opportunity to see the three water falls from close by.

Those who love the masterpieces of Mother Nature should travel further West to the Canadian Rockies. There is a great chance they find their favorite placed on Earth there. The mountains are so majestic and serene. There are high sharp peaks and lush valleys, formed as a result of the glacial ice in the region.

There are five national parks located in the Canadian Rockies. One of them of course is Banff, the oldest National Park in the country. It was established in 1885 and consists of 2500 acres of land. Its glaciers and meadows are great setting to every holiday picture. Those who like to ski will definitely enjoy their stay at Banff but just be careful because you have to share the park with all sorts of wild animals, like grizzly bears, cougars and wolves.

Canada is not a place only for those who like to explore the nature and the Old Quebec City is a proof of that. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site that works as a time machine taking you back to the 19th century. The city was very well protected by the Fortifications of Quebec and the Citadel which now are just a tourist attractions and the silhouette of the Notre-Dame-de-Québec Basilica-Cathedral is impressive. The historic district is more than 400 years old since it was founded by Samuel de Champlain in 1608. If you are up for an adventure why not trying to stay in the hotel made entirely out of ice.

And if you are into old cities with their unique spirit that brings out the best of the past, don’t miss Old Montreal as well. It has a strong European character with cozy nooks and winding streets. You don’t need a strict plan and schedule just stroll along the district and at some point you will simply forget what year it is.

Imagine one beautiful pristine island. Now imagine Thousand islands or actually 1864. This is what you will find in the Saint Lawrence River right before it emerges from the Ontario Lake. Actually you might have tasted the Thousand Islands without even being there because the archipelago gave its name to the famous salad dressing made of mayonnaise, olive oil, lemon juice and mustard.

If the Thousand islands seem too many, you can simply choose to follow the steps of the English explorer William Baffin and go to the island named after him. Baffin Island is the largest in Canada and the fifth largest in the world. Polar bears feel at home around its glacier-capped mountains. The island is a great place for people who enjoy extreme sports activities like kayaking, cliff jumping and ice climbing.

item.title: Five unmissable South African trips
item.dc:creator: Guest Poster
item.description: Every country has its fair share of diversity, but South Africa takes the prize for the most culturally stirred melting pot of wildlife and nightclubs, friendly locals and Moorish food. It’s almost as if the best bits of Africa slowly Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Every country has its fair share of diversity, but South Africa takes the prize for the most culturally stirred melting pot of wildlife and nightclubs, friendly locals and Moorish food. It’s almost as if the best bits of Africa slowly trickled down all the rivers and streams, marshlands and swamps and finally settled in one bursting country at the bottom of the world’s most fascinating continent.

With its vibrant cities, wildlife saturated landscapes and an ever undulating terrain, you’d be forgiven if you are slightly overwhelmed when planning your trip to South Africa. Luckily enough, we’re here to give you a helping hand, so you can sit back and relax with no worries on your flight to Johannesburg.

 For the gastro enthusiast

There are some of us that tour the world to taste its countless spices and savour its rich wines – and there’s no better destination for sampling than the valleys and mountains of South Africa. Tour the wine lands of the Cape where you’ll find the country’s most acclaimed grapes rubbing shoulders with delicate chocolatiers, tempting bakeries and spicy traditional dishes.

If you get the chance, make time to eat at a local shebeen or township (unlicensed restaurants and bars). Here you’ll find the best home-made food and strongest home brewed booze, along with some good, local company.

For the family

You can’t take the kids to South Africa with promises of big animals and not head to Kruger National Park. The park is home to a whopping 147 species of mammal, 507 birds and 114 reptiles – and that’s before bugs, trees, fish and amphibians make it into the mix.

There are plenty of child-friendly tours and hotels out there to make sure that the little ones get the most out of their South African safari (and that mum and dad aren’t so distracted they miss out on spotting the Big Five).

 For the adrenaline junkie

If you’re looking for adventure on your trip to South Africa, heading to the country’s most iconic natural landmark, Table Mountain, is a sure fire way to get the blood pumping. If you decide to hike the 1,085m to the very top, there are a multitude of options to get you back to the bottom again – whether you choose to abseil back down, hire a mountain bike or take the leap with a paraglide strapped to your back, there’s something for every adrenaline seeking adventurer out there.

 For the beach bum

Grotto Beach, which sits to the south-east of Cape Town, is an idyllic escape for anyone who loves to sit and watch the rolling waves lap the sand and enjoy the glorious sun beating on their skin. Grotto Beach is also home to some of the world’s best land-based whale watching, so you can get your wildlife fix without cutting into your beach time…

For beachside cuisine with a little luxury, head to Dutchies Restaurant for fresh seafood, local wine and a beachside view for dessert.

 For the culture vulture

Since the 17th Century, the UNESCO World Heritage site of Robben Island has been used as a prison, a hospital for socially unacceptable groups and a military base. It’s most famous inhabitant, Nelson Mandela, spent 18 of his 27 prison years here.

The island is home to old WWII military structures, an old leper’s church, some small remains of a leper colony and the barren structures of the high security prison, along with some 17th Century quarries and the tomb of Hadije Kramat. Heading to Robben Island is the perfect day trip for history buffs and ramblers alike.

item.title: The grass is always greener… on the other side
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.description: I always find it interesting when I stop to think about life and deep stuff like that. The other day while having such a thought, I came to the conclusion that we all seem to be programed to desire things Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
I always find it interesting when I stop to think about life and deep stuff like that. The other day while having such a thought, I came to the conclusion that we all seem to be programed to desire things we don’t have. Maybe it’s natures way of equilibrating us, or maybe a greater power is just setting us on a course of perpetual wanting. While traveling we have seen several quirky things that are complete contradictions to what our society sees as the norm, and vice versa.

Self image

If you have ever spent any time on the beaches of Thailand, or most of SE Asia, you have surely seen the vendors walking the beach in non-beach-appropriate gear. Long pants, long sleeve shirts, and a huge hat. The reason for this is they do not want to darken their skin, because to them having darker complexion is a sign of poverty, meaning that you have to work outside to make a living. So it must be strange to these vendors to see crowds of westerns who have come to their beach for the specific purpose of sitting in the sun, and darkening their skin.

Covered head to toe!

Do you remember back in middle school when you were forced to braces on your teeth, and the teasing you received for it. So could you imaging wearing braces just for fashions sake? Well a current trend in SE Asia has teens wearing a face full of phony metal. They are wearing braces that aren’t real braces, they don’t actually fix your teeth. Why would you do it? Status! Braces are expensive, so one way to make it look like you have money, even though you may not, is to wear fake braces.

My cousin Hattie sporting her mouth metal!

Geographic Jealousy

Every year thousands of people risk their lives and everything they own to live in the country I call home, all the while I can’t wait to leave it. On the other hand every long term traveler’s blog talks about getting home sick, and burning out on travel. We all seem to want to be somewhere we aren’t.

Jobs and $$$$

The last few years, for most people, has been pretty rough economically. We have personally weathered the financial storm rather well, and job security wise don’t have much to complain about. While many people are looking for work I am running away from it. So maybe I should feel guilty tossing my good paying job to the side to travel.

Time and place

Wants and desires within your own life can change, and this has happen to me a few times in ways that relate to travel. In college I thought it was a huge waste of time that I had to take two semesters of English for me as an engineering student. A funny turn of events leads me to writing for you, and authoring a blog, something I would have never thought I would desire. I now find myself at the library more than ever, checking out books on writing style and composition. Another prerequisite I had while attending university was to learn a foreign language. Fast forward 7 years, and I am kicking myself that I just did the bare minimum to get through the classes, only retaining very basic Spanish skills. Only to pay once again to learn Spanish, although the location will be much better than the basement of the arts building this time around. We plan to take a set of three separate weeks of Spanish while in the early part of our trip in Mexico, Guatemala, and Nicaragua.

item.title: Meet a Traveler- Interview with Almost Fearless Backpackers
item.dc:creator: Hannah
item.description: Meet Ashley & Chris from Almost Fearless Backpackers The who are you ?’s 1. Who are you and where do you hail from? -We are Jexter and well, we don’t hail – we like to think of ourselves more like Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Meet Ashley & Chris from Almost Fearless Backpackers

The who are you ?’s

1. Who are you and where do you hail from?

-We are Jexter and well, we don’t hail – we like to think of ourselves more like a rainbow because many people don’t like hail but always love a rainbow . We departed from Toronto just 2 average Canadians on a mission, deciding to drop everything to just travel. We really don’t like saying we put our lives on hold (as many do say), because our life is honestly just beginning.

2. How did you meet your partner in crime? How long have you known each other?

-As far as the parents know, we met at a concert because at the age of 18 and 19 they wouldn’t approve of meeting over Facebook. But now you know the truth and they still don’t We’ve known eachother for about 3 and a half years now and just got engaged on December 25th, 2012.

3. What jobs did you kick to the curb in order to travel?

-Chris had his job cooking, but didnt kick it to the curb because traveling is just another experience in his culinary career. And as far as Ashley goes, she just finished school for becoming a counsellor specifically to work with assaulted women and children.

4. Explain your website name, where did it come from/how did you come up with it?

-Ohhh this is a tough one to explain. We spent numerous hours arguing and asking everyone for help disliking most of their ideas and could never agree on anything. Finally we came up with Almost Fearless Backpackers, because well, obviously we’re not fearless but we like to think we’re almost there.

The fun ?’s

1. What’s the most under-estimated country & why?

-Bulgaria. Everyone always asks “Oh, why Bulgaria?” or “Oh, why do you want to go there?”. Our response:  Why the f*** not!! It is an amazing country, from the people to the culture and let’s not forget about the amazing food and the Rakia that knocks a lot of people off their feet.

2. What’s your biggest travel mishap?

When you are about to embark on your adventure of a lifetime, you expect everything to be great…am I right? Well this wasn’t the case for Ashley. Ashley’s worst travel experience was the plane ride from her home town to the start of Jexter’s adventures, London, England. An 8 hour flight is already pretty bad, but now imagine getting that feeling where you are starting to get the common cold – body aches, stuffy nose and sore throat – AND having to sit next to someone who managed to take up half of your seat AND snored the entire plane ride…what a great start to our adventure, eh?

3. What luxuries did you forgoe in order to save for your travels?

-Save money? Haha. We have practically no money. We love travel too much to let money get in the way, First trip Chris went on he left with $300 cash and a credit card for about 3 months. The next trip (Ashley and Chris) was for 6 months and we left with $2100 cash combined and two credit cards. We work pretty much off credit, then come home and bust our balls to pay it off just in time for our next trip with some cash.

4. What country has the best $1usd menu? What can one expect to get for $1usd?

-Similar to the 1st fun question, Bulgaria. You can get an amazing salad that will insure that you never want to have another salad anywhere else, because it can’t meet the standards of a true Bulgarian salad with white cheese. All for 1 dollar!

Quick & Dirty (1-2 word answers)

1. Favorite beach

-Oh this is a tough one, we have been to some amazing beaches and don’t think we could pick just one.

2. #1 must have travel items

Sorry can’t pick just one. But a heart and balls. You need to love what you’re doing and go to each destination with an open heart and welcome it all in with love because if you don’t you will regret it and miss out on a lot. And then you need to grow a pair because if you’re always scared to do something, or say hi to someone, or try something new, you never know what your missing from like meeting the love of your life or trying the most amazing food in your life or even missing out on an opportunity to have the most life changing experience ever.

3. Zip-off pants or no zip-off pants

-No zip-off pants.

4. Favorite beer

-Ashley is not a beer drinker, but for Chris by far it’s Alexanders Keith’s from Halifax, NS, Canada.

5. Favorite ice-cream flavor?

-Chris- BUBBLE GUM ALL THE WAY (or bacon *Drool Face*) Ashley- any type of sorbet, ice cream makes her stomach sick.

6. How many stamps in your passport?

-Ashley’s is packed up with 17 and Chris has 28.

Website: http://www.almostfearlessbackpackers.com/

Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/AlmostFearlessBackpackers

item.title: The Sights of Majorca
item.dc:creator: Guest Poster
item.description: Spending an exciting holiday on a sunny island used to be privilege of the rich and famous in Europe for decades. Now it is affordable and easy. People just hop on a plane and a few hours later they lie Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Spending an exciting holiday on a sunny island used to be privilege of the rich and famous in Europe for decades. Now it is affordable and easy. People just hop on a plane and a few hours later they lie on a sunny beach sipping cocktails and enjoy the sun and the Mediterranean Sea.

Let’s take Majorca for example. The largest of the Balearic Islands was a distant dream for the regular tourists in the 1950s. Now there are not so many things that are easier than organizing a memorable holiday on the island. There are so many planes landing and taking off from Palma de Majorca airport that the more difficult part is probably just picking which airline to use. You can even spontaneously grab some luggage and the car keys and head towards your closest airport. Check Parking4less for the best parking option there and leave for the paradise island.

But if you think Majorca can offer only endless beaches, sunshine and incredible sea holiday, think again. The capital Palma is charming with its historical and architectural sites, with the little streets meandering around the cathedral and the calmness that can exist only at an island. But the hidden treasures of Majorca are the small towns which combine the charm of the tourist destinations and the quietness of the past times.

Places like Pollensa which is a popular destination for tourists and still has this rustic spirit. The real attractions there are the traditional houses. Most of them were built during the 17th century while the church is 400 years older. A walk around the narrow streets will take you back in time to the years when the Moorish ruled the town.

Throughout the centuries Majorca was not only a place to rest and forget about the hustle of the continent, it was also an inspiration. Great artists like Joan Miró and Chopin worked there. May be the reason for that inspiration was the breathtaking Majorcan nature. On the island tourists can find stunning mountain views, steep cliffs, and fascinating gulfs. One of the most scenic roads in the world lead to Cap de Formentor. According to the old Majorcan legend, all the winds gather there. It is a vertical cliff right above the sea providing unique views not only towards Majorca but also towards the neighboring Menorca.

As if Cap de Fermentor was not enough, Mother Nature gave Majorca another treasure hidden bellow the ground level. On the east coast of the island close to the town of Porto Cristo everyday visitors gather around Coves del Drach – four great 2.5 kilometers long caves formed naturally by the Mediterranean Sea. The most impressive scenery is provided probably by Lake Martel. This is one of the largest underground lakes in the world. It is more than  1-kilometer long.

If you want to feel the real spirit of Majorca, there is only one place to go – Soller. The town is set in a green valley surrounded by the highest mountains in Majorca on three sides and the sea on the fourth. The vintage train that runs through Soller brings additional charm while the impressive silhouette of the San Bartomeu Church dominates the town. Soller itself is like an open air museum of the 18th century providing excellent introduction to the traditional Majorcan houses.

The roads from Soller lead to Serra de Tramuntana – the highest mountain range on the island. It is awarded World Heritage Status by UNESCO.  The variety offered by the mountain is hard to be believed. No matter if you choose to hike or bike, the West Majorcan coast will provide an unforgettable adventure.

item.title: The Worlds Best Bars
item.dc:creator: Adam
item.description: As we travel we love to explore the bar culture of whatever city we find ourselves in, so we decided to compile a list of our favorite bars. Some we have been to, and some we can’t wait to get Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
As we travel we love to explore the bar culture of whatever city we find ourselves in, so we decided to compile a list of our favorite bars. Some we have been to, and some we can’t wait to get to while we circle the globe on our RTW trip!

Best Dive Bar – Rudy’s – New York, New York

Where else can you get a real New York hotdog with every drink purchase? Quirky charm is all over this bar, from its red duct tape upholstered booths, to the 6 foot pig statue that greets you at the door. In true dive bar fashion the drinks are priced right, beers starting at just $2.50 /pint, which is pretty good considering Times Square is only a few blocks over.

Best off the beaten track bar – The Pelican Bar – Jamaica

You can’t get much further off the path that the Pelican bar, its actually not even on a path, the only way to get to this bar is by boat! Once a board this oasis you can suck Red Stripes while hanging your feet in the turquoises waters off the coast of Jamaica.

Best Bar With A View – Lebua Sky Bar – Bangkok,Thailand

You may remember this bar from its recent appearance in the movie the Hangover 2, shot in Bangkok, Thailand. The bars most stunning feature is the panoramic views of bustling Bangkok. Boasting the world’s highest open air bar at 63 floors up!

Hidden Gem – Old Mary’s – London, U.K.

This bar looks straight out of Dickens, and is frequently rated as one of the best bars in London. This basement level bar ran by a brewery and offers up a good selection of craft beers as well as, of course, Bloody Mary’s!

Best Themed Bar – Contra Bar – Manuel Antiono, Costa Rica

The bar is located in old military plane said to be left over from the Contra conflict. This bar comes complete with a full bar in the fuselage, and real bullet holes!

Best Adrenalin Rush Bar – Rick’s Cafe – Negril, Jamacia

Nothing works up a good appetite for some drinks than jumping of a 40 ft (12m) platform into the Caribbean sea. Quench your thirst with a Red Stripe! You can catch a cab to Rick’s from any resort, or there are a bunch of cruises that will stop for a jump too.

What’s your favorite bar in the world? We need some suggestion of places for a beer while traveling! Post yours in the comments!
